frontmatter.title: Programming language semantics: It's easy as 1,2,3

mainmatter.p: Programming language semantics is an important topic in theoretical computer science, but one that beginners often find challenging. This article provides a tutorial introduction to the subject, in which the language of integers and addition is used as a minimal setting in which to present a range of semantic concepts in simple manner
I decided to read one paper or article every week. This week's topic is programming language semantics, refer to Graham Huttons's paper Programming language semantics: It's easy as 1,2,3.

Semantics is the general term for the study of meaning. Programming language semantics gives precise mathematical meaning to programs. We use a simple arithmetic expression language (including integers and addition only) to illustrate the basic concepts. This is an example of Occam's razor, a philosophical principle that favours the simplest explanation for a phenomenon.

frontmatter.title: Introduction to Programming Language Semantic › Arithmetic Expressions

mainmatter.p: Now let's define our language of arithmetic expressions built up from the set of integers and the operation of addition. Use a context-free grammar. E: \equiv \mathbb {Z} | E+E E:≡Z∣E+E E: \equiv \mathbb {Z} | E+E E:≡Z∣E+E

An expression is either an integer value or the addition of two sub-expressions. We assume that parentheses can be freely used as required to disambiguate expressions written in normal textual form. This grammar can be easily translated into a Haskell data type.

pre.code: data Expr = Val Integer | Add Expr Expr

frontmatter.title: Introduction to Programming Language Semantic › Denotational Semantics

mainmatter.p: Now we consider denotational semantics, where the terms in a language is defined using a valuation function that maps terms into values in an appropriate semantic domain.

Formally, for a language TTTT of syntactic terms comprises two components: a set VVVV of semantic values and a valuation function of type T \to VT→VT \to VT→V that maps terms to their meanings as values. This function is written by enclosing a term in a semantic brackets (Also known as Oxford or Strachey brackets), writing \llbracket t \rrbracket⟦t⟧\llbracket t \rrbracket[[t]] for the value of term tttt. In addition, the valuation function is required to be compositional, the meaning of a compound term is defined purely in terms of the meaning of its sub-terms.

Compositionality aids understanding by ensuring that the semantics is modular and supports the use of simple equational reasoning techniques for proving properties of the semantics. When the set of semantic values is clear, a denotational semantics is often identified with the underlying valuation function.

Taking VVVV the Haskell type Integer of integers and define a valuation function of type Expr -> Integer (by following equations) we can define the denotational semantics of our expression language. \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Val} \space n \rrbracket &= n \\ \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket &= \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket \end {align*} ⟦Val n⟧=n⟦Add e1 e2⟧=⟦e1⟧+⟦e2⟧ \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Val} \space n \rrbracket &= n \\ \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket &= \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket \end {align*} [[Val n]][[Add e1​ e2​]]​=n=[[e1​]]+[[e2​]]​ This definition satisfies the compositionality requirement obviously. Note that the symbol ++++ has two different purposes. On the left side, it is a syntactic constructor for building terms, while on the right side, it is a semantic operator for adding integers.

Compositionality simplifies reasoning because it allows us to replace equals by equals. For example, \frac { \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket = n_1 \quad \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket = n_2 }{ \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket = \llbracket \text {Add} \space n_1 \space n_2 \rrbracket } ⟦e1⟧=n1⟦e2⟧=n2⟦Add e1 e2⟧=⟦Add n1 n2⟧ \frac { \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket = n_1 \quad \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket = n_2 }{ \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket = \llbracket \text {Add} \space n_1 \space n_2 \rrbracket } [[Add e1​ e2​]]=[[Add n1​ n2​]][[e1​]]=n1​[[e2​]]=n2​​ we can freely replace the two argument expressions of an addition by other expressions with the same meanings, and the meaning of the whole addition will remain unchanged. Using the definition of the valuation function, we can prove this property. \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket &= \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket ( \text {By definition of } \llbracket- \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket n_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket n_2 \rrbracket ( \text {Assumptions}) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space n_1 \space n_2 \rrbracket ( \text {By definition of } \llbracket- \rrbracket ) \end {align*} ⟦Add e1 e2⟧=⟦e1⟧+⟦e2⟧(By definition of ⟦−⟧)=⟦n1⟧+⟦n2⟧(Assumptions)=⟦Add n1 n2⟧(By definition of ⟦−⟧) \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2 \rrbracket &= \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket ( \text {By definition of } \llbracket- \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket n_1 \rrbracket + \llbracket n_2 \rrbracket ( \text {Assumptions}) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space n_1 \space n_2 \rrbracket ( \text {By definition of } \llbracket- \rrbracket ) \end {align*} [[Add e1​ e2​]]​=[[e1​]]+[[e2​]](By definition of [[−]])=[[n1​]]+[[n2​]](Assumptions)=[[Add n1​ n2​]](By definition of [[−]])​

Given that terms and their semantics are built up inductively, proofs about denotational semantics typically proceed using structural induction. Let us show that our expression semantics is total, that is, for every expression eeee there is an integer nnnn such that \llbracket e \rrbracket = n⟦e⟧=n\llbracket e \rrbracket = n[[e]]=n.

tree.mainmatter: For the base case e = \text {Val} \space ne=Val ne = \text {Val} \space ne=Val n, we have \llbracket e \rrbracket = n⟦e⟧=n\llbracket e \rrbracket = n[[e]]=n trivially. For the inductive case e = \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2e=Add e1 e2e = \text {Add} \space e_1 \space e_2e=Add e1​ e2​, we can assume by induction that \llbracket e_1 \rrbracket = n_1⟦e1⟧=n1\llbracket e_1 \rrbracket = n_1[[e1​]]=n1​ and \llbracket e_2 \rrbracket = n_2⟦e2⟧=n2\llbracket e_2 \rrbracket = n_2[[e2​]]=n2​ for some integers n_1n1n_1n1​ and n_2n2n_2n2​. Then \llbracket e \rrbracket = n_1 + n_2⟦e⟧=n1+n2\llbracket e \rrbracket = n_1 + n_2[[e]]=n1​+n2​ by definition of the valuation function, indicates this case is also true. Therefore, the semantics is total.

mainmatter.p: The valuation function can be translated into a Haskell function

pre.code: eval :: Expr -> Integer eval (Val n) = n eval (Add x y) = eval x + eval y

mainmatter.p: More generally, a denotational semantics can be viewed as an evaluator (or interpreter). Even eval is defined recursively, the semantics is compositional its behavior can be understood as simply replacing the constructors for expressions by other functions. In this manner, a denotational semantics can also be viewed as an evaluation function that is defined by folding over the syntax of the source language.

pre.code: eval :: Expr -> Integer eval = fold id (+)

mainmatter.p: The fold operator captures the ideas of replacing constructors of the language by other functions

pre.code: fold :: (Integer -> a) -> (a -> a -> a) -> Expr -> a fold f g (Val n) = f n fold f g (Add x y) = g (fold f g x) (fold f g y)

mainmatter.p: Note that the above semantics for expressions does not specify the order of evaluation. If we do wish to make evaluation order explicit this requires the introduction of additional structure into the semantics, named abstract machines (Discuss later).

frontmatter.title: Introduction to Programming Language Semantic › Small-Step Operational Semantics

mainmatter.p:
Another popular approach to semantics is the operational approach, where the meaning of terms is defined using an execution relation that specifies how terms can be executed in an appropriate machine model. There are two basic forms of operational semantics:
small-step: describes the individual steps of execution
big-step: describes the overall results of execution
In this section we consider the small-step approach, which is also known as structural operational semantics.

Formally, a small-step operational semantics for a language TTTT of syntactic terms comprises two components: a set SSSS of execution states and a transition relation of type S \to SS→SS \to SS→S that specifies how terms can be executed. If there is a transition from state ssss to state s's′s's′ in a single execution step, we write s \to s's→s′s \to s's→s′.

Arithmetic expressions have a simple small-step operational semantics, given by taking SSSS as the Haskell type. And we define transition relation on Expr by the following inference rules. \begin {align*} \frac {}{ \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2) \to \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2) } \\ \frac {x \to x'}{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \to \text {Add} \space x' \space y} \quad \frac {y \to y'}{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \to \text {Add} \space x \space y'} \end {align*} Add (Val n1) (Val n2)→Val (n1+n2)x→x′Add x y→Add x′ yy→y′Add x y→Add x y′ \begin {align*} \frac {}{ \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2) \to \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2) } \\ \frac {x \to x'}{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \to \text {Add} \space x' \space y} \quad \frac {y \to y'}{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \to \text {Add} \space x \space y'} \end {align*} Add (Val n1​) (Val n2​)→Val (n1​+n2​)​Add x y→Add x′ yx→x′​Add x y→Add x y′y→y′​​

The first rule states that two values can be added to give a single value and is called a reduction (or contraction) rule. An expression that matches such a rule is termed a reducible expression or redex. The last two rules are called structural (or congruence) rules as they specify how larger terms can be reduced.

The semantics is non-deterministic because an expression may have more than one possible transition. This is obviously from the structural rules, which allow either sub-expression to be reduced first.

We can now capture a the relation between the denotational and operational semantics, namely that making a transition does not change the denotation of an expression. \frac { e \to e' }{ \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket } e→e′⟦e⟧=⟦e′⟧ \frac { e \to e' }{ \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket } [[e]]=[[e′]]e→e′​ This property can be proved by induction on the structure of the expression eeee. Note that by using the "equals by equals" and the assumption x \to x'x→x′x \to x'x→x′ we can easily prove the inductive case. The details are omitted here as it involves quite a bit of case analysis. We will later see the principle of rule induction, which gives a simpler and more direct way to prove such properties.

Evaluation of an expression using the small-step semantics proceeds by a series of zero or more transition steps. Formally we can write e \to ^* e'e→∗e′e \to ^* e'e→∗e′ to indicate that eeee can be reduced to e'e′e'e′ in zero or more steps. We can generate a transition tree that captures all possible execution paths for an expression. Using the list comprehension we can define a function that returns the list of all expressions that can be reduced from a given expression eeee in a single transition.

pre.code: trans :: Expr -> [Expr] trans (Val n) = [] trans (Add (Val n) (Val m)) = [Val (n + m)] trans (Add x y) = [Add x' y | x' <- trans x] ++ [Add x y' | y' <- trans y]

mainmatter.p: We can define a Haskell datatype for transition trees and an execution function that converts expressions into transition trees.

pre.code: data Tree a = Node a [Tree a] exec :: Expr -> Tree Expr exec e = Node e [exec e' | e' <- trans e]

mainmatter.p: Though exec is defined recursively, its behavior can be understood as simply applying the identity function to give the root of the tree and the transition function to generate a list of residual expressions to be processed to give the subtrees. A small-step semantics can be viewed as giving rise to an execution function that is defined by unfolding to transition trees.

pre.code: exec :: Expr -> Tree Expr exec = unfold id trans

mainmatter.p: The unfold function captures the idea of generating a tree from a seed value xxxx by applying a function ffff to give the root and a function gggg to give a list of residual values to be processed for the subtrees.

pre.code: unfold :: (t -> a) -> (t -> [t]) -> t -> Tree a unfold f g x = Node (f x) [unfold f g x' | x' <- g x]

mainmatter.p: The operational semantics corresponds to unfolding to transition trees, while denotational semantics corresponds to folding over syntax trees. Thinking about semantics in terms of recursion operators reveals a duality

The above semantics for expressions does not specify the order of evaluation. But we can modify the inference rules to achieve this. Replace the second \text {Add}Add\text {Add}Add rule by the following rule ensures the first argument of addition is always reduced first. \frac { y \to y' }{ \text {Add} ( \text {Val} \space n) \space y \to \text {Add} ( \text {Val} \space n) \space y' } y→y′Add(Val n) y→Add(Val n) y′ \frac { y \to y' }{ \text {Add} ( \text {Val} \space n) \space y \to \text {Add} ( \text {Val} \space n) \space y' } Add(Val n) y→Add(Val n) y′y→y′​

frontmatter.title: Introduction to Programming Language Semantic › Rule induction

mainmatter.p: For denotational semantics we have structural induction, dual to this, for operational semantics we have rule induction. This allows us to perform proofs by considering the structure of the rules that are used to define the semantics.

We introduce the idea of rule induction using a simple numeric example. We begin by inductively defining a set of natural numbers. \frac {}{0 \in \mathbb {N} } \quad \frac {n \in \mathbb {N} }{n+1 \in \mathbb {N} } 0∈Nn∈Nn+1∈N \frac {}{0 \in \mathbb {N} } \quad \frac {n \in \mathbb {N} }{n+1 \in \mathbb {N} } 0∈N​n+1∈Nn∈N​ This is the standard definition of the natural numbers using peano axioms, where the first rule states that zero is a natural number and the second rule states that if nnnn is a natural number then so is n+1n+1n+1n+1.

For the inductively defined set \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N. The principle of rule induction states that in order to prove a property P(n)P(n)P(n)P(n) for all natural numbers nnnn, it suffices to prove that P(0)P(0)P(0)P(0) holds and that if P(n)P(n)P(n)P(n) holds then P(n+1)P(n+1)P(n+1)P(n+1) holds. \frac { P(0) \quad \forall n \in \mathbb {N} . P(n) \to P(n+1) }{ \forall n \in \mathbb {N} . P(n) } P(0)∀n∈N.P(n)→P(n+1)∀n∈N.P(n) \frac { P(0) \quad \forall n \in \mathbb {N} . P(n) \to P(n+1) }{ \forall n \in \mathbb {N} . P(n) } ∀n∈N.P(n)P(0)∀n∈N.P(n)→P(n+1)​ Notice that this is the well-known principle of mathematical induction.

The concept of rule induction can easily be generalised to multiple base and inductive cases, to rule with multiple preconditions and so on. For the small-step semantics of expressions, we have one base case and two inductive cases. Hence if we want to show that some property P(e,e')P(e,e′)P(e,e')P(e,e′) on pairs of expression holds for all transition e \to e'e→e′e \to e'e→e′, we can use rule induction: \frac { \begin {align*} P( \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2), \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2)) \\ \forall x \to x'. P(x,x') \to P( \text {Add} \space x \space y, \text {Add} \space x' \space y) \\ \forall y \to y'. P(y,y') \to P( \text {Add} \space x \space y, \text {Add} \space x \space y') \end {align*} }{ \forall e \to e'. P(e,e') } P(Add (Val n1) (Val n2),Val (n1+n2))∀x→x′.P(x,x′)→P(Add x y,Add x′ y)∀y→y′.P(y,y′)→P(Add x y,Add x y′)∀e→e′.P(e,e′) \frac { \begin {align*} P( \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2), \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2)) \\ \forall x \to x'. P(x,x') \to P( \text {Add} \space x \space y, \text {Add} \space x' \space y) \\ \forall y \to y'. P(y,y') \to P( \text {Add} \space x \space y, \text {Add} \space x \space y') \end {align*} }{ \forall e \to e'. P(e,e') } ∀e→e′.P(e,e′)P(Add (Val n1​) (Val n2​),Val (n1​+n2​))∀x→x′.P(x,x′)→P(Add x y,Add x′ y)∀y→y′.P(y,y′)→P(Add x y,Add x y′)​​ We write \forall x \to y.P(x,y)∀x→y.P(x,y)\forall x \to y.P(x,y)∀x→y.P(x,y) as shorthand for \forall x,y.x \to y \Rightarrow P(x,y)∀x,y.x→y⇒P(x,y)\forall x,y.x \to y \Rightarrow P(x,y)∀x,y.x→y⇒P(x,y). Now we give the proof of the property \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket⟦e⟧=⟦e′⟧\llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket[[e]]=[[e′]] for all transitions e \to e'e→e′e \to e'e→e′. \forall e \to e'. \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket ∀e→e′.⟦e⟧=⟦e′⟧ \forall e \to e'. \llbracket e \rrbracket = \llbracket e' \rrbracket ∀e→e′.[[e]]=[[e′]]

tree.mainmatter: The proof consists of three parts: the base case, the reduction rule and the structural rule. \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space ( \text {Val} \space m) \rrbracket &= \llbracket \text {Val} \space n \rrbracket + \llbracket \text {Val} \space m \rrbracket \\ &= n + m \\ &= \llbracket \text {Val} \space (n+m) \rrbracket \end {align*} ⟦Add (Val n) (Val m)⟧=⟦Val n⟧+⟦Val m⟧=n+m=⟦Val (n+m)⟧ \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space ( \text {Val} \space m) \rrbracket &= \llbracket \text {Val} \space n \rrbracket + \llbracket \text {Val} \space m \rrbracket \\ &= n + m \\ &= \llbracket \text {Val} \space (n+m) \rrbracket \end {align*} [[Add (Val n) (Val m)]]​=[[Val n]]+[[Val m]]=n+m=[[Val (n+m)]]​ and \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y \rrbracket &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket \\ &= \llbracket x' \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket ( \text {By assumption } \llbracket x \rrbracket = \llbracket x' \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space x' \space y \rrbracket \end {align*} ⟦Add x y⟧=⟦x⟧+⟦y⟧=⟦x′⟧+⟦y⟧(By assumption ⟦x⟧=⟦x′⟧)=⟦Add x′ y⟧ \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y \rrbracket &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket \\ &= \llbracket x' \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket ( \text {By assumption } \llbracket x \rrbracket = \llbracket x' \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space x' \space y \rrbracket \end {align*} [[Add x y]]​=[[x]]+[[y]]=[[x′]]+[[y]](By assumption [[x]]=[[x′]])=[[Add x′ y]]​ and \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y \rrbracket &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket \\ &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y' \rrbracket ( \text {By assumption } \llbracket y \rrbracket = \llbracket y' \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y' \rrbracket \end {align*} ⟦Add x y⟧=⟦x⟧+⟦y⟧=⟦x⟧+⟦y′⟧(By assumption ⟦y⟧=⟦y′⟧)=⟦Add x y′⟧ \begin {align*} \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y \rrbracket &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y \rrbracket \\ &= \llbracket x \rrbracket + \llbracket y' \rrbracket ( \text {By assumption } \llbracket y \rrbracket = \llbracket y' \rrbracket ) \\ &= \llbracket \text {Add} \space x \space y' \rrbracket \end {align*} [[Add x y]]​=[[x]]+[[y]]=[[x]]+[[y′]](By assumption [[y]]=[[y′]])=[[Add x y′]]​

frontmatter.title: Introduction to Programming Language Semantic › Contextual Semantics

mainmatter.p: The small-step semantics for expressions above has one basic reduction rule for adding values and two structural rules that allow addition to be performed in larger expressions. Separating these two kinds of rules results the notion of contextual semantics (or reduction semantics).

Informally, a context in this setting is a term with a "hole", usually written as [-][−][-][−], which can be filled with another term later. In a contextual semantics, the hole represents the location where a single basic step of execution may take place within a term.

Consider the following transition in our small-step semantics. (1+2)+(3+4) \to 3+(3+4) (1+2)+(3+4)→3+(3+4) (1+2)+(3+4) \to 3+(3+4) (1+2)+(3+4)→3+(3+4) The addition is performed on the left side. We say that we can perform the basic step 1+2 \to31+2→31+2 \to31+2→3 in the context [-] +(3+4)[−]+(3+4)[-] +(3+4)[−]+(3+4) where [-][−][-][−] implies the location of the addition takes place.

The language CCCC of contexts of arithmetic expressions can be formally defined by C: \equiv [-] |C+E|E+C C:≡[−]∣C+E∣E+C C: \equiv [-] |C+E|E+C C:≡[−]∣C+E∣E+C As previously, we can define a Haskell datatype for contexts.

pre.code: data Cont = Hole | Add Cont Expr | Add Expr Cont

mainmatter.p: The kind of context is known as "outside-in" as locating the hole involves navigating from the outside of the context inwards. To fill the hole in a context cccc with an expression eeee we write c \space [e]c [e]c \space [e]c [e]: \begin {align*} \text {Hole} \space [e] &= e \\ ( \text {AddL} \space c \space r ) \space [e] &= \text {Add} \space (c \space [e]) \space r \\ ( \text {AddR} \space l \space c ) \space [e] &= \text {Add} \space l \space (c \space [e]) \end {align*} Hole [e]=e(AddL c r) [e]=Add (c [e]) r(AddR l c) [e]=Add l (c [e]) \begin {align*} \text {Hole} \space [e] &= e \\ ( \text {AddL} \space c \space r ) \space [e] &= \text {Add} \space (c \space [e]) \space r \\ ( \text {AddR} \space l \space c ) \space [e] &= \text {Add} \space l \space (c \space [e]) \end {align*} Hole [e](AddL c r) [e](AddR l c) [e]​=e=Add (c [e]) r=Add l (c [e])​

Use the idea of hole filling we can redefine the small-step semantics for expressions in contextual style. \frac {}{ \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2) \rightarrowtail \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2) } \quad \frac { e \rightarrowtail e' }{ c \space [e] \to c \space [e'] } Add (Val n1) (Val n2)↣Val (n1+n2)e↣e′c [e]→c [e′] \frac {}{ \text {Add} \space ( \text {Val} \space n_1) \space ( \text {Val} \space n_2) \rightarrowtail \text {Val} \space (n_1+n_2) } \quad \frac { e \rightarrowtail e' }{ c \space [e] \to c \space [e'] } Add (Val n1​) (Val n2​)↣Val (n1​+n2​)​c [e]→c [e′]e↣e′​ This first rule defines a reduction relation \rightarrowtail↣\rightarrowtail↣ that captures the basic behavior of addition, while the second defines a transition relation \to→\to→ that allows the first rule to be applied in any context.

We have now refactored the small-step semantics into a single reduction rule and a single structural rule. If we subsequently want to extend the language with other features, it only requires adding new reduction rules and extending the notion of contexts but not need to adding new structural rules.
Now we define the hole filling function in Haskell.

pre.code: fill :: Cont -> Expr -> Expr fill Hole e = e fill (AddL c r) e = Add (fill c e) r fill (AddR l c) e = Add l (fill c e)

mainmatter.p: The dual operation which splits an expression into all possible pairs of contexts and expressions can be defined:

pre.code: split :: Expr -> [(Cont,Expr)] split e = (Hole, e) : case e of Val n -> [] Add l r -> [(AddL c r, x) | (c, x) <- split l] ++ [(AddR l c, x) | (c, x) <- split r]

mainmatter.p: A pair (c,x)(c,x)(c,x)(c,x) comprising a context #[c] and an expression xxxx is an element of the list returned by split e precisely when fill c x = e. The contextual semantics can be translated into Haskell function that returns the lists of all expressions that can be reached by performing a single reduction step.

pre.code: reduce :: Expr -> [Expr] reduce (Add (Val n) (Val m)) = [Val (n + m)] reduce _ = []

mainmatter.p: or a single transition step.

pre.code: trans :: Expr -> [Expr] trans e = [fill c x' | (c, x) <- split e, x' <- reduce x]

mainmatter.p: This function splits the given expression into all possible context and expression pairs, then considering any reduction that can made by each component expression, and finally filling the hole in the context with the reduced expression.

Notice that the contextual semantics does not specify an evaluation order for addition and is non-deterministic. We can modify the language of contexts to achieve so. C: \equiv [-] |C+E| \mathbb {Z} +C C:≡[−]∣C+E∣Z+C C: \equiv [-] |C+E| \mathbb {Z} +C C:≡[−]∣C+E∣Z+C This version of the semantics also satisfies a unique decomposition property, that is, any expression eeee that is not a value can be uniquely decomposed into the form e=c \space [x]e=c [x]e=c \space [x]e=c [x] for some context cccc and reducible expression xxxx. This can be proved by induction on the expression eeee.
Contexts are related to a number of other important concepts in programming and semantics, including the use of continuations to make control flow explicit (John C. Reynolds 1972).

frontmatter.title: Introduction to Programming Language Semantic › Big-step Semantics

mainmatter.p: Big-step semantics is also known as natural semantics, which focus on large execution step. For a language T of syntactic terms comprises two components: a set VVVV of values and an evaluation relation between TTTT and VVVV that relates each term to all values that can be reached by fully executing the term. If a term tttt and a value vvvv are related, we say that tttt can evaluate to vvvv and write this as t \Downarrow vt⇓vt \Downarrow vt⇓v
mainmatter.tex: \frac {}{ \text {Val} \space n \Downarrow n } \quad \frac { x \Downarrow n \quad y \Downarrow m }{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \Downarrow n+m } Val n⇓nx⇓ny⇓mAdd x y⇓n+m \frac {}{ \text {Val} \space n \Downarrow n } \quad \frac { x \Downarrow n \quad y \Downarrow m }{ \text {Add} \space x \space y \Downarrow n+m } Val n⇓n​Add x y⇓n+mx⇓ny⇓m​
mainmatter.p: The Haskell function definition is similar to the small-step semantics, by using the list comprehension.

pre.code: eval :: Expr -> [Integer] eval (Val n) = [n] eval (Add x y) = [n + m | n <- eval x, m <- eval y]

mainmatter.p: This is similar to denotational semantics but using inference rules rather than a functional manner. However, there is no need for a big-step semantics to be compositional. Formally, the denotational and big-step semantics for the expression language are equivalent, which can be captured by the following property: \llbracket e \rrbracket = n \iff e \Downarrow n ⟦e⟧=n  ⟺  e⇓n \llbracket e \rrbracket = n \iff e \Downarrow n [[e]]=n⟺e⇓n This is easily verified by induction.

frontmatter.title: Introduction to Programming Language Semantic › Abstract Machine

mainmatter.p: All the exmaples we have meet focused on explaining semantic ideas, now we show how language of integers and addition can also be used to help discover semantic ideas. We show how it can be used as the basis for discovering how to implement an abstract machine.
Remember the evaluation order problem we meet before, if we want to make evaluation order explicit, we can introduce additional structure into the semantics by constructing an abstract machine.

Formally, an abstract machine is usually deifned by a set of syntactic rewrite ruless that make explicit how each step of evaluation proceeds. This section we show how an abstract machine for our example language can be systematically derived from the evaluation function using steps based on two important semantic concepts, continuations and defunctionalisation.
We want to make the order of evaluation explicit in the semantics itself. A standard technique for achieving this aim is to rewrite the semantics in continuation-passing style.

In our setting, a continuation is a function that will be applied to the result of an evaluation. Formally, for our semantics eval :: Expr -> Integer, a continuation is a function of type Integer -> Integer that will be applied to the resulting integer to give a new integer. (This type can be generalized to Integer -> a, but we do not need now) We capture the notion of such a continuation using the following type declaration:

pre.code: type Continuation = Integer -> Integer

mainmatter.p: We now define a new semantics \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′, which takes an expression and returns an integer as previously but also takes a continuation as an additional argument, which is applied to the result of evaluating the expression.

pre.code: eval' :: Expr -> Continuation -> Integer

mainmatter.p: The behavior of \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′ should be:
mainmatter.tex: \text {eval}' \space e \space c = \text {c (eval e)} eval′ e c=c (eval e) \text {eval}' \space e \space c = \text {c (eval e)} eval′ e c=c (eval e)
mainmatter.p: We want to calculate a definition that satisfies the specification. Using structural induction on the expression eeee, we construct the term \text {eval}' \space e \space ceval′ e c\text {eval}' \space e \space ceval′ e c by gradually removing the reference to eval. For the base case, e = \text {Val} \space ne=Val ne = \text {Val} \space ne=Val n we have
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space c &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space ( \text {Val} \space n)) \\ &= c \space n \end {align*} eval′ (Val n) c=c (eval (Val n))=c n \begin {align*} \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space c &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space ( \text {Val} \space n)) \\ &= c \space n \end {align*} eval′ (Val n) c​=c (eval (Val n))=c n​
mainmatter.p: For the inductive case, e = \text {Add} \space x \space ye=Add x ye = \text {Add} \space x \space ye=Add x y we begin in the same way:
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space c &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y)) \\ &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space x + \text {eval} \space y) \end {align*} eval′ (Add x y) c=c (eval (Add x y))=c (eval x+eval y) \begin {align*} \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space c &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y)) \\ &= c \space ( \text {eval} \space x + \text {eval} \space y) \end {align*} eval′ (Add x y) c​=c (eval (Add x y))=c (eval x+eval y)​
mainmatter.p: However, no further definition can be applied now, so we consider the inductive hypothesis: Forall c'c′c'c′ and c''c′′c''c′′ we have \text {eval}' \space x \space c' = c'( \text {eval} \space x)eval′ x c′=c′(eval x)\text {eval}' \space x \space c' = c'( \text {eval} \space x)eval′ x c′=c′(eval x) and \text {eval}' \space y \space c'' = c''( \text {eval} \space y)eval′ y c′′=c′′(eval y)\text {eval}' \space y \space c'' = c''( \text {eval} \space y)eval′ y c′′=c′′(eval y). This can readily be achieved by abstracting over \text {eval} \space xeval x\text {eval} \space xeval x and \text {eval} \space yeval y\text {eval} \space yeval y using lambda abstraction.
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} & c \space ( \text {eval} \space x + \text {eval} \space y) \\ =& ( \lambda n \to c \space (n+ \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to c \space (n+ \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to ( \lambda m \to c \space (n+m))( \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to \text {eval}' \space y \space ( \lambda m \to c \space (n+m))) \end {align*} c (eval x+eval y)=(λn→c (n+eval y))=eval′ x (λn→c (n+eval y))=eval′ x (λn→(λm→c (n+m))(eval y))=eval′ x (λn→eval′ y (λm→c (n+m))) \begin {align*} & c \space ( \text {eval} \space x + \text {eval} \space y) \\ =& ( \lambda n \to c \space (n+ \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to c \space (n+ \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to ( \lambda m \to c \space (n+m))( \text {eval} \space y)) \\ =& \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \lambda n \to \text {eval}' \space y \space ( \lambda m \to c \space (n+m))) \end {align*} ====​c (eval x+eval y)(λn→c (n+eval y))eval′ x (λn→c (n+eval y))eval′ x (λn→(λm→c (n+m))(eval y))eval′ x (λn→eval′ y (λm→c (n+m)))​
mainmatter.p: The final term does not refer to \text {eval}eval\text {eval}eval now. In summary we have calculated the following definition

pre.code: eval' :: Expr -> Continuation -> Integer eval' (Val n) c = c n eval' (Add x y) c = eval' x (\n -> eval' y (\m -> c (n + m)))

mainmatter.p: Our original semantics can be recovered from the new semantics by using the identity continuation \lambda n \to nλn→n\lambda n \to nλn→n

pre.code: eval e = eval' e (\n -> n)

mainmatter.p: We use continuation to make the order of evaluation explicit in the semantics, but this also makes the semantics into a higher-order function. Hence our second step is to regain the first-order nature of the original semantics by eliminating the use of continuations but retaining the explicit order of evaluation they introduced.

A standard technique for eliminating the use of functions as arguments is defunctionalisation. We do not usually need the entire function-space of possible argument functions, there only a few forms of such functions are actually used. Hence we represent the argument functions that we actually need using a datatype rather than functions.
We begin by defining three combinators halt, next and add for constructing the continuations we used.

pre.code:
halt :: Continuation halt n = n
next :: Expr -> Continuation -> Continuation next y c = \n -> eval' y (add n c)
add :: Integer -> Continuation -> Continuation add n c = \m -> c (n + m)

mainmatter.p: Use the combinators, our continuation semantics can now be written as:

pre.code:
eval :: Expr -> Integer eavl e = eval' e halt
eval' :: Expr -> Continuation -> Integer eval' (Val n) c = c n eval' (Add x y) c = eval' x (next y c)

mainmatter.p: Now we declare a new datatype for continuations, consists of three constructors.

pre.code: data CONT = HALT | NEXT Expr CONT | ADD Integer CONT

mainmatter.p: The following translation function forms a denotational semantics for CONT

pre.code: exec :: CONT -> Continuation exec HALT = halt exec (NEXT y c) = next y (exec c) exec (ADD n c) = add n (exec c)

mainmatter.p: This function is usually called apply, which can be viewed as applying a representation of a continuation to an integer to give another integer. We want to define a new semantics \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′ which behaves in the same way as our previous \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′ except that it uses values of type CONT rather than Continuation. eval'' :: Expr -> CONT -> Integer The desired behavior of \text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′ is: \text {eval}'' \space e \space c = \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \text {exec} \space c) eval′′ e c=eval′ e (exec c) \text {eval}'' \space e \space c = \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \text {exec} \space c) eval′′ e c=eval′ e (exec c)

As before, we proceed by structural induction on expression eeee. The base case e= \text {Val} \space ne=Val ne= \text {Val} \space ne=Val n is trivial \begin {align*} \text {eval}'' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space c &= \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space ( \text {exec} \space c) \\ &= \text {exec} \space c \space n \\ \end {align*} eval′′ (Val n) c=eval′ (Val n) (exec c)=exec c n \begin {align*} \text {eval}'' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space c &= \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Val} \space n) \space ( \text {exec} \space c) \\ &= \text {exec} \space c \space n \\ \end {align*} eval′′ (Val n) c​=eval′ (Val n) (exec c)=exec c n​

For the inductive case e = \text {Add} \space x \space ye=Add x ye = \text {Add} \space x \space ye=Add x y: \begin {align*} \text {eval}'' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space c &= \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space ( \text {exec} \space c) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \text {next} \space y \space ( \text {exec} \space c)) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \text {exec} \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c)) \\ &= \text {eval}'' \space x \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c) \end {align*} eval′′ (Add x y) c=eval′ (Add x y) (exec c)=eval′ x (next y (exec c))=eval′ x (exec (NEXT y c))=eval′′ x (NEXT y c) \begin {align*} \text {eval}'' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space c &= \text {eval}' \space ( \text {Add} \space x \space y) \space ( \text {exec} \space c) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \text {next} \space y \space ( \text {exec} \space c)) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space x \space ( \text {exec} \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c)) \\ &= \text {eval}'' \space x \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c) \end {align*} eval′′ (Add x y) c​=eval′ (Add x y) (exec c)=eval′ x (next y (exec c))=eval′ x (exec (NEXT y c))=eval′′ x (NEXT y c)​ The last step uses the inductive hypothesis for xxxx

In the basic case, \text {exec}exec\text {exec}exec still refers to the semantic \text {eval}'eval′\text {eval}'eval′, via the combinator \text {next}next\text {next}next. Hence we need to compute a new definition for \text {exec}exec\text {exec}exec that refers to our new \text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′.
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {exec} \space \text {HALT} \space n &= \text {halt} \space n \\ &= n \end {align*} exec HALT n=halt n=n \begin {align*} \text {exec} \space \text {HALT} \space n &= \text {halt} \space n \\ &= n \end {align*} exec HALT n​=halt n=n​
mainmatter.p: The other case is also easy to compute, no need to induction.
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {exec} \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c) \space n &= \text {eval}'' \space y \space ( \text {ADD} \space n \space c) \\ \text {exec} \space ( \text {ADD} \space n \space c) \space m &= \text {exec} \space c \space (n+m) \end {align*} exec (NEXT y c) n=eval′′ y (ADD n c)exec (ADD n c) m=exec c (n+m) \begin {align*} \text {exec} \space ( \text {NEXT} \space y \space c) \space n &= \text {eval}'' \space y \space ( \text {ADD} \space n \space c) \\ \text {exec} \space ( \text {ADD} \space n \space c) \space m &= \text {exec} \space c \space (n+m) \end {align*} exec (NEXT y c) nexec (ADD n c) m​=eval′′ y (ADD n c)=exec c (n+m)​
mainmatter.p: Our original semantics \text {eval}eval\text {eval}eval can be recovered from the new semantics \text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′ too.
mainmatter.tex: \begin {align*} \text {eval} \space e &= \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \lambda n \to n) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space e \space \text {halt} \\ &= \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \text {exec} \space \text {HALT} ) \\ &= \text {eval}'' \space e \text {HALT} \end {align*} eval e=eval′ e (λn→n)=eval′ e halt=eval′ e (exec HALT)=eval′′ eHALT \begin {align*} \text {eval} \space e &= \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \lambda n \to n) \\ &= \text {eval}' \space e \space \text {halt} \\ &= \text {eval}' \space e \space ( \text {exec} \space \text {HALT} ) \\ &= \text {eval}'' \space e \text {HALT} \end {align*} eval e​=eval′ e (λn→n)=eval′ e halt=eval′ e (exec HALT)=eval′′ eHALT​
mainmatter.p: In summary, we have calculated the following definitions:

pre.code:
eval'' :: Expr -> CONT -> Integer eval'' (Val n) c = exec c n eval'' (Add x y) c = eval'' x (NEXT y c)
exec :: CONT -> Integer -> Integer exec HALT n = n exec (NEXT y c) n = eval'' y (ADD n c) exec (ADD n c) m = exec c (n + m)
eval :: Expr -> Integer eval e = eval'' e HALT

mainmatter.p: The four components (\text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′, \text {eval}eval\text {eval}eval, \text {exec}exec\text {exec}exec and CONT) forms an abstract machine.

CONT is the type of control stack which comprises instructions that determine how the machine should continue after evaluating the current expression. Sometimes it is called an "eval/continue" machine. The control stack can also be defined as a list of instructions.
type CONT = [INST] data INST = NEXT Expr | ADD Integer
\text {eval}eval\text {eval}eval evaluates an expression and give an integer by simply call the \text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′ with empty control stack \text {HALT}HALT\text {HALT}HALT.

\text {eval}''eval′′\text {eval}''eval′′ evaluates an expression in the context of a control stack. If the expression is an integer, we execute the control stack using this integer as an argument. If the expression is an addition, we evaluate the first argument xxxx and place the instruction \text {NEXT} \space yNEXT y\text {NEXT} \space yNEXT y on the top of the control stack.

\text {exec}exec\text {exec}exec executes the control stack. If the control stack is empty, then just return the integer argument as the result. If the top instruction is \text {NEXT} \space yNEXT y\text {NEXT} \space yNEXT y, we evaluate yyyy and place the instruction \text {ADD} \space nADD n\text {ADD} \space nADD n to the stack top. If the top instruction is \text {ADD} \space nADD n\text {ADD} \space nADD n,evaluation of the two arguments of an addition is complete, and we execute the remaining control stack in the context of the sum of the resulting integers.
